title: 'Shocked and surprised,' Nobel Medicine winners celebrate
text:
Dr. Gregg Semenza... the latest scientist to join the Nobel Medicine Prize club... says it took multiple calls on Monday morning for the Nobel Assembly to wake him and deliver the news.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) DR. GREGG SEMENZA, ONE OF THREE DOCTORS WHO WON THE 2019 NOBEL MEDICINE PRIZE, SAYING:

"I was in a daze. I was kind of half awake. It was kind of... a kind of... I was not able to say much of anything because I was so shocked and surprised."

Semenza and fellow doctors William Kaelin of Harvard Medical School and Sir Peter Ratcliffe of Oxford University shared this year's prize... awarded for discoveries relating to how our bodies respond to oxygen.

After a visit to his lab at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland, Semenza described oxygen as fundamental.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) DR. GREGG SEMENZA, ONE OF THREE DOCTORS WHO WON THE 2019 NOBEL MEDICINE PRIZE, SAYING:

"How does the body ensure that it gets enough oxygen for every cell to survive? It's sort of the most fundamental requirement there is. You can just hold your breath and you'll know there's nothing you can do without for a shorter period of time than oxygen."

The Nobel Assembly said their discoveries could help create new ways to fight anemia, cancer and heart failure, among other diseases.

It added that applications of their findings are already starting to affect the way medicine is practiced.

At the U.S. Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, fellow winner Kaelin dedicated the award to his late wife Carolyn, who was also a doctor at the Institute.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) DR. WILLIAM KAELIN, ONE OF THREE DOCTORS WHO WON THE 2019 NOBEL MEDICINE PRIZE, SAYING:

"Carolyn was about excellence and integrity and compassion in everything she did, so I try to hold myself to those very high standards, to try to conduct my work in the proper way. It's not about frankly the awards and accolades, although they're wonderful when they come, but it's about trying to get to the truth, and to generate new knowledge, and have that knowledge hopefully help our patients."

Medicine is the first of the Novel Prizes given each year.
